Dispersion in two dimensional channels - the Fick-Jacobs approximation revisited

M. Mangeat â€ƒâ€ƒ T. GuÃ©rin â€ƒâ€ƒ D. S. Dean Laboratoire Ondes et MatiÃ¨re dâ€™Aquitaine (LOMA), CNRS, UMR 5798 / UniversitÃ© de Bordeaux, F-33400 Talence, France
Abstract

We examine the dispersion of Brownian particles in a symmetric two dimensional channel, this classical problem has been widely studied in the literature using the so called Fick-Jacobsâ€™ approximation and its various improvements. Most studies rely on the reduction to an effective one dimensional diffusion equation, here we derive an explicit formula for the diffusion constant which avoids this reduction. Using this formula the effective diffusion constant can be evaluated numerically without resorting to Brownian simulations. In addition, a perturbation theory can be developed in Îµ=h0/Lğœ€subscriptâ„0ğ¿\varepsilon=h_{0}/L where h0subscriptâ„0h_{0} is the characteristic channel height and Lğ¿L the period. This perturbation theory confirms the results of Kalinay and Percus (Phys. Rev. E 74, 041203 (2006)), based on the reduction, to one dimensional diffusion are exact at least to ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ6)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}). Furthermore, we show how the Kalinay and Percus pseudo-linear approximation can be straightforwardly recovered. The approach proposed here can also be exploited to yield exact results in the limit Îµâ†’âˆâ†’ğœ€\varepsilon\to\infty, we show that here the diffusion constant remains finite and show how the result can be obtained with a simple physical argument. Moreover, we show that the correction to the effective diffusion constant is of order 1/Îµ1ğœ€1/\varepsilon and remarkably has a some universal characteristics. Numerically we compare the analytic results obtained with exact numerical calculations for a number of interesting channel geometries.

I Introduction

The dispersion properties of complex systems have a wide range of applications including solid state physics, soft matter physics, biology and chemical engineering van2007 ; gar1985 . In many cases the effective transport properties, such as the late time diffusion constant and effective drift are important quantities to study problems as varied as mixing leBorgne2013stretching ; dentz2011mixing ; barros2012flow , sorting bernate2012stochastic , contaminant spreading brusseau1994transport or reaction kinetics in complex systems con2007 . The computation of such effective transport quantities is a longstanding problem in statistical physics and exploits techniques ranging from probability theory kel1962 through to quantum field theory dea2007 .

Transport, notably diffusion, in channel like geometries arises in a number of important physical contexts, ranging from biophysics through to the study of porous media burada2009diffusion ; malgaretti2013entropic ; bressloff2013stochastic ; holcman2013control . Dispersion in periodic systems such as hard squares or disks placed on a lattice can also be mapped onto diffusion in channel like systems dag2012b . Even if the underlying process in such problems is locally standard Brownian motion, the interplay between geometry and diffusion gives rise to rich behavior, for instance the slowing down of diffusive dispersion due to entropic trapping. In many contexts one is only interested in dispersion along the channel and the problem of computing the effective diffusion constant parallel to the channel is one which has been intensively studied. The first results on diffusion in channels are attributed to Jacobs in Ref. jac1967 where the first form of what is known as the Fick-Jacobsâ€™ (FJ) approximation was derived. Subsequent works zwa1991 ; reg2001 ; kal2005 ; kal2006 ; mar2011 ; bra2009 ; ber2011a ; dag2012 involved improvements to the basic FJ approximation for both two dimensional channels and axisymmetric channels in three dimensions. These studies are based on the effective reduction of the problem of diffusion in the channel, to a one dimensional problem where a particle diffuses in an entropically generated potential, simply related to the local channel width or area, but with an effective local diffusion constant. Once this reduction is carried out the effective diffusion constant can be computed using exact results for the diffusion constant of one-dimensional systems lif1961 ; rei2001 ; costantini1999 .

One of the most successful approaches to the problem of diffusion in a channel was proposed by Kalinay and Percus in Refs.Â kal2005 ; kal2006 . Here they express the effective local diffusion constant as an expansion in powers of a parameter Îµğœ€\varepsilon proportional to the ratio of the typical relaxation times in the perpendicular and parallel direction. Later studies dorfman2014assessing checked that such expansions lead to expressions of the global effective diffusivity that are exact at least to order ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€4\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{4}). From a probabilistic point of view this latter result is somewhat surprising as the effective process parallel to the channel can clearly never be Markovian and described by an effective one dimensional diffusion equation. Mathematically similar problems, where a higher dimensional Markovian stochastic processes is reduced to a lower dimensional one, occur throughout the physics literature, notably when partially-damped Langevin equations (describing the velocity and position of a particle) are reduced to over-damped Langevin equations (describing only the position). A similar problem arises for a particle carrying a dipole in a spatially varying electric field, here the Langevin equations describing the dipole moment and the position can be reduced to a Langevin equation for just the position. In the class of problems mentioned above, a mathematical process of adiabatic elimination, which amounts to a perturbation expansion in the time scale for the relaxation of the quick variable (velocity or dipole moment for instance) divided by that of the slow position variable can be applied. In most cases the effective process remains Markovian only to first order in perturbation theory mig1980 ; ris1996 ; tou2009 . In this paper we neglect hydrodynamic effects, these can become important for fluid filled channels yang2017 when the particle size becomes comparable to the channel size. This is due to the spatial variation of the local diffusion tensor as one approaches the walls channel. Here we restrict our attention to the dispersion of a point-like particle and we can thus ignore these hydrodynamic effects.

In this paper, we analyze in section II the FJ problem starting from an exact formula for the longitudinal diffusion constant. The formula is derived here using a physical argument for channels in any dimension, and agrees with general Kubo type formulas derived for advection diffusion equations in periodic systems gue2015a ; gue2015b and with the macroscopic transport theory developed by Brenner bre1993 . Then, for two-dimensional channels, we present in section III a very compact analysis which allows us to show in section IV that the results of Ref.Â kal2006 are exact to ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ6)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}), whereas to date they had been checked only up to ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€4{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{4}) by using Brennerâ€™s theory dorfman2014assessing . Given what we have stated about adiabatic approximations above, it is very interesting that the method of Ref.Â kal2006 stays correct up to such a high order. We obtain this result within a formalism that uses analytic functions in a complex plane, and we show in section V how the pseudo-linear approximation of Kalinay and Percus can be recovered. This approximation is based on neglecting terms Wâ€²â€²â€‹(x)superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²ğ‘¥W^{\prime\prime}(x) (where Wğ‘ŠW is the local channel width) and higher order derivatives. In section VI, we show how the diffusion constant can be computed exactly for a class of two dimensional channels which can be appropriately parameterized in the complex plane, this reproduces in a very rapid manner the classical result of Zwanzig zwa1982 . We also show in section VII how the same formalism can be applied to the limit Îµâ†’âˆâ†’ğœ€\varepsilon\to\infty, the exact opposite of the cases usually studied in the literature and in which all approaches based on a dimensional reduction fail. In this limit Îµâ†’âˆâ†’ğœ€\varepsilon\to\infty, we find the asymptotic value of the diffusion constant (which is non-zero) and we also compute the leading order correction, which is ğ’ªâ€‹(1/Îµ)ğ’ª1ğœ€{\cal O}(1/\varepsilon), and which has a prefactor that has a remarkably universal character. A short description of this result was given in man2017 , the derivation presented here is slightly different, as we concentrate here on two dimensional channels, and relies more heavily on complex analysis. Finally, in section VIII we show how the formalism based on the Kubo formula for the diffusion constant can be used to numerically study a wide range of channel geometries, thus avoiding the statistical errors and longer times associated with Brownian simulations. We compare some of the standard variants of the FJ approximation with these results for a number of channel geometries, as well as the high order perturbation theory and large Îµğœ€\varepsilon results derived here.

II General equations for diffusion in channels

II.1 Model

In this section, we consider diffusion in a portion of space located between two surfaces of equations y=h1â€‹(ğ±)ğ‘¦subscriptâ„1ğ±y=h_{1}({\bf x}) and y=h2â€‹(ğ±)ğ‘¦subscriptâ„2ğ±y=h_{2}({\bf x}). We consider the diffusion of a tracer with isotropic diffusion in the channel, with diffusion constant Dğ·D, and subject to a uniform drift velocity parallel to the channel ğ®||{\bf u}_{||}. The probability density function (pdf) for the tracer thus obeys the advection-diffusion equation

II.3 The basic Fick-Jacobsâ€™ approximation

The physical validity of this approximation is argued to hold when the process relaxes in the yğ‘¦y direction very quickly with respect to its motion in the direction parallel to the channel; it should hold when Hâ€‹(ğ±)â‰ªLmuch-less-thanğ»ğ±ğ¿H({\bf x})\ll L where Lğ¿L is the length scale over which the total channel width varies. An alternative limit where it holds is when one takes the diffusion to be anisotropic, having a (isotropic) diffusion constant D||D_{||} in the plane and a different diffusion constant DâŸ‚subscriptğ·perpendicular-toD_{\perp} in the perpendicular direction. The FJ approximation then holds in the limit Îµ=D||/DâŸ‚â‰ª1\varepsilon=D_{||}/D_{\perp}\ll 1, and the problem can be analyzed perturbatively using Îµğœ€\varepsilon as the small parameter. Of course the approximation that pâ€‹(ğ±,y;t)ğ‘ğ±ğ‘¦ğ‘¡p({\bf x},y;t) is independent of yğ‘¦y clearly does not satisfy the no flux boundary condition in Eq.Â (4) when âˆ‡||hÎ±â‰ ğŸ\nabla_{||}h_{\alpha}\neq{\bf 0}. An important success of the FJ approximation is that it gives the correct equilibrium distribution in the steady state. On a unit cell Î©Î©\Omega of the channel (which is repeated to form the infinite channel) the equilibrium distribution is clearly uniform within the channel and thus the marginal pdf for the in plane coordinate ğ±ğ±{\bf x} is

Psâ€‹(ğ±)=Hâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ«Î©ğ‘‘ğ±â€²â€‹Hâ€‹(ğ±â€²).subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ ğ±ğ»ğ±subscriptÎ©differential-dsuperscriptğ±â€²ğ»superscriptğ±â€²P_{s}({\bf x})=\frac{H({\bf x})}{\int_{\Omega}d{\bf x^{\prime}}H({\bf x^{\prime}})}. (12)

This means that the ğ±ğ±{\bf x} in-plane coordinate of the tracer particle is subjected to an effective entropic potential

For effectively two dimensional systems (that is to say two dimensional channels or three dimensional ones with rotational symmetry) a number of authors have suggested improvements to the Fick-Jacobs approximation in the form an effective in plane diffusion constant Dâ€‹(x)ğ·ğ‘¥D(x) which depends on the local height functions (in general both h2subscriptâ„2h_{2} and h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} and not just their difference). Clearly if an underlying one dimensional diffusion equation were to exist it would have to have the steady state distribution given by Eq.Â (12) and thus have the general form, in the absence of external drift,

âˆ‚pâˆ—âˆ‚tâ€‹(x;t)=âˆ‚âˆ‚xâ€‹Dâ€‹(x)â€‹[âˆ‚pâˆ—âˆ‚xâ€‹(x;t)+Î²â€‹âˆ‚Ï•entâˆ‚xâ€‹(x)â€‹pâˆ—â€‹(x;t)],superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘¥delimited-[]superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ›½subscriptitalic-Ï•entğ‘¥ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial t}(x;t)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}D(x)\left[\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial x}(x;t)+\beta\frac{\partial\phi_{\rm ent}}{\partial x}(x)p^{*}(x;t)\right], (14)

with Î²=1/kBâ€‹Tğ›½1subscriptğ‘˜ğµğ‘‡\beta=1/k_{B}T. The effective diffusion constant for the effective one dimensional problem can then be extracted using the exact formula for one dimensional diffusion lif1961

De=1âŸ¨Dâˆ’1â€‹(x)â€‹expâ¡(Î²â€‹Ï•entâ€‹(x))âŸ©sâ€‹âŸ¨expâ¡(âˆ’Î²â€‹Ï•entâ€‹(x))âŸ©s,subscriptğ·ğ‘’1subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ·1ğ‘¥ğ›½subscriptitalic-Ï•entğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›½subscriptitalic-Ï•entğ‘¥ğ‘ D_{e}=\frac{1}{\langle D^{-1}(x)\exp\left(\beta\phi_{\rm ent}(x)\right)\rangle_{s}\langle\exp\left(-\beta\phi_{\rm ent}(x)\right)\rangle_{s}}, (15)

where the angled bracket indicate the spatial average over one period of the system, i.e.

âŸ¨fâŸ©s=1Lâ€‹âˆ«0Lğ‘‘xâ€‹fâ€‹(x).subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘“ğ‘ 1ğ¿superscriptsubscript0ğ¿differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥\langle f\rangle_{s}=\frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{L}dx\ f(x). (16)

These approaches all agree in an expansion based on Îµ=DâŸ‚/D||\varepsilon=D_{\perp}/D_{||} being small but differ at higher orders. However, as mentioned in the introduction, this approach clearly cannot be valid exactly as the process projected onto the in-plane coordinates is evidently not Markovian and thus cannot be described by a diffusion equation with local transport coefficients. As mentioned in the introduction, a similar phenomenon appears in the theory of stochastic processes where a fast variable is eliminated from a stochastic differential equation using an adiabatic approximation scheme mig1980 ; ris1996 ; tou2009 . It is generally found that the process remains Markovian at the first order of correction but does not remain so when higher order corrections are included.

II.4 General formula for the diffusion constant

In this paper we will use an exact formula for the diffusion constant, of the process in the plane of the channel, which does not use a reduction of the problem to a lower dimensional one. The formulas for the diffusion constant can be directly written down using a general theory for diffusion in periodic systems developed in gue2015a ; gue2015b . These formulas are formally exact â€“ however, they require the solution of partial differential equations which are not analytically soluble in two dimensions and higher. Nevertheless, the relevant equations can be treated using approximation methods for narrow channel geometries which are similar to those which are employed to derive improvements to the FJ approximation and which are used as the basis for lubrication theory in fluid dynamics lub .

From now on, we consider that h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} and h2subscriptâ„2h_{2} are spatially periodic, and of the same periodicity. Rather than simply quoting the results of gue2015a ; gue2015b , we provide a quick re derivation of the result, ideally suited to the channel geometry and based on simple physical arguments. To begin with we compete the average drift of a tracer in the in plane coordinates,

dâ€‹âŸ¨XiâŸ©dâ€‹t=âˆ«ğ‘‘ğ±â€‹ğ‘‘yâ€‹xiâ€‹âˆ‚pâˆ‚tâ€‹(ğ±,y;t)=âˆ«ğ‘‘ğ±â€‹xiâ€‹âˆ‚pâˆ—âˆ‚tâ€‹(ğ±,t),ğ‘‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘¡differential-dğ±differential-dğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ±ğ‘¦ğ‘¡differential-dğ±subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ±ğ‘¡\frac{d\langle X_{i}\rangle}{dt}=\int d{\bf x}dy\ x_{i}\frac{\partial p}{\partial t}({\bf x},y;t)=\int d{\bf x}\ x_{i}\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial t}({\bf x},t), (17)

III Formulation of the problem with analytic functions for two dimensional symmetric channels

Most studies in the literature have considered the case where the channel is two dimensional. IV.2 Perturbation theory in channel width

In Ref.Â dorfman2014assessing the effective macroscopic transport theory of Brenner bre1993 was used. The expression for the diffusion constant in this theory can actually be shown to agree with the Kubo formula derived here. An interesting point made in Ref.Â dorfman2014assessing is that the result of Ref.Â kal2006 is recovered at orders up to and including Îµ4superscriptğœ€4\varepsilon^{4}.

V The pseudo-linear channel approximation

In Ref.Â kal2006 the perturbation theory was partially resumed by assuming that derivatives Î¶â€²â€²superscriptğœâ€²â€²\zeta^{\prime\prime} and of higher order vanish. Here we show how this re summation can be derived within the formalism developed here in a very compact manner. We start from the Eq.Â (38) and make the ansatz

VII The large Îµğœ€\varepsilon limit

Here we can consider the case of very wide channels where we again write hâ€‹(x)=Îµâ€‹Î¶â€‹(x)â„ğ‘¥ğœ€ğœğ‘¥h(x)=\varepsilon\zeta(x) but we assume that Îµâ†’âˆâ†’ğœ€\varepsilon\to\infty. Before analyzing this problem via the formalism developed above we propose a simple physical argument which gives a bound on the diffusion constant. Consider a symmetric channel whose height function about the center of the channel achieves its minimum value at some point xminsubscriptğ‘¥minx_{\rm min} where it takes the value hminsubscriptâ„minh_{\rm min}. Without loss of generality we choose xmin=âˆ’1/2â‰¡1/2subscriptğ‘¥min1212x_{\rm min}=-1/2\equiv 1/2. Now while the particle is in the region Î©â€²=[âˆ’1/2,1/2]Ã—[âˆ’hmin,hmin]superscriptÎ©â€²1212subscriptâ„minsubscriptâ„min\Omega^{\prime}=[-1/2,1/2]\times[-h_{\rm min},h_{\rm min}] the particle diffuses without hindrance from the sides of the channel, so we can write

ddâ€‹tâ€‹âŸ¨X2âŸ©=2â€‹D,ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¡delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘‹22ğ·\frac{d}{dt}\langle X^{2}\rangle=2D, (98)

however, outside of this region the diffusion is slowed down. If we denote by tÎ©â€²subscriptğ‘¡superscriptÎ©â€²t_{\Omega^{\prime}} the total time spent in Î©â€²superscriptÎ©â€²\Omega^{\prime} we can thus write

âŸ¨X2âŸ©â‰¥2â€‹Dâ€‹tÎ©â€²,delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘‹22ğ·subscriptğ‘¡superscriptÎ©â€²\langle X^{2}\rangle\geq 2Dt_{\Omega^{\prime}}, (99)

because time spent in the region where the walls can interfere with the diffusion will nonetheless contribute to diffusion - for example consider small excursions into this region which come back into Î©â€²superscriptÎ©â€²\Omega^{\prime} having moved along the channel.

As we know the equilibrium distribution in the channel modulo the period is uniform, ergodicity then implies that

tÎ©â€²t=|Î©â€²||Î©|=hminâŸ¨hâŸ©ssubscriptğ‘¡superscriptÎ©â€²ğ‘¡superscriptÎ©â€²Î©subscriptâ„minsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©â„ğ‘ \frac{t_{\Omega^{\prime}}}{t}=\frac{|\Omega^{\prime}|}{|\Omega|}=\frac{h_{\rm min}}{\langle h\rangle_{s}} (100)

which gives the bound

âŸ¨X2âŸ©â‰¥2â€‹Dâ€‹hminâŸ¨hâŸ©sâ€‹tdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘‹22ğ·subscriptâ„minsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©â„ğ‘ ğ‘¡\langle X^{2}\rangle\geq 2D\frac{h_{\rm min}}{\langle h\rangle_{s}}t (101)

and thus we have the bound on the effective diffusion constant along the channel

DeDâ‰¥hminâŸ¨hâŸ©s=Î¶minâŸ¨Î¶âŸ©s.subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ·subscriptâ„minsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©â„ğ‘ subscriptğœminsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœğ‘ \frac{D_{e}}{D}\geq\frac{h_{\rm min}}{\langle h\rangle_{s}}=\frac{\zeta_{\rm min}}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}. (102)

It is also clear that Deâ‰¤Dsubscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ·D_{e}\leq D and thus we have the two sided bound

1â‰¥DeDâ‰¥Î¶minâŸ¨Î¶âŸ©s,1subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ·subscriptğœminsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœğ‘ 1\geq\frac{D_{e}}{D}\geq\frac{\zeta_{\rm min}}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}, (103)

and this simple result shows one that the system has a finite diffusion coefficient even in the limit Îµâ†’âˆâ†’ğœ€\varepsilon\to\infty. In dea1993 diffusion on comb-like locally one dimensional structures was studied. The comb consists of a one dimensional backbone along which the diffusion is measured with teeth perpendicular to the backbone, excursions into the teeth slow down diffusion along the background. In this case the lower bound in Eq.Â (103) becomes exact as no diffusion can occur in the teeth due to their one dimensional character and given they are perpendicular to the backbone. Other problems of biased diffusion in tubes with dead-ends are studied in goo1960 ; dag2007 ; ber2011b .

To go beyond this analysis we consider a channel where the points x=Â±1/2ğ‘¥plus-or-minus12x=\pm 1/2 correspond to the minimum of the height of the channel. VIII Numerical results

In this section we will show how the diffusion constant for periodic channels may be computed numerically. We use a standard finite element partial differential equation solver to (i) solve Laplaceâ€™s equation Eq.Â (25) with the integral constraint Eq.Â (26) and the boundary condition in Eq.Â (27) and (ii) carryout the subsequent evaluation of the effective diffusion constant via Eq.Â (24). The results obtained are used to test some of the analytical results derived here and elsewhere in the literature.

VIII.1 The exact result of Zwanzig

In zwa1982 Zwanzig considered a symmetric channel parameterized using the curvilinear coordinate system defined by

z=w+aâ€‹sinâ¡(w),ğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘¤z=w+a\sin(w), (110)

which is equivalent to

xğ‘¥\displaystyle x =\displaystyle= u+aâ€‹coshâ¡(v)â€‹sinâ¡(u)ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¢\displaystyle u+a\cosh(v)\sin(u) (111)

where the boundaries of the channel are given by v=Â±Vğ‘£plus-or-minusğ‘‰v=\pm V. The height of the channel is single valued for Î±=aâ€‹coshâ¡(V)<1ğ›¼ğ‘ğ‘‰1\alpha=a\cosh(V)<1. An example of such a channel is shown in Fig.Â 2a.

In this case Zwanzig showed that

DeD=11+Î±2â€‹tanhâ¡(V)V,subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ·11superscriptğ›¼2ğ‘‰ğ‘‰\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{\alpha^{2}\tanh(V)}{V}}, (113)

which can be easily verified using Eq.Â (97). The existence of this exact result serves as a useful verification of the general formulas derived here for the diffusion equation (Eqs.Â (24-27)) along with our numerical resolution of the associated partial differential equations. The effective diffusion constant is shown in Fig.Â 2b for a channel with periodicity 2â€‹Ï€2ğœ‹2\pi with V=0.5ğ‘‰0.5V=0.5 for values of ağ‘a taken between 00 (the flat channel) through to the maximal value of ağ‘a for which the channel height is a single valued function - the agreement is seen to be perfect.

VIII.3 Smooth channel

In this section we consider the case of a smoothly varying channel where all terms appearing in the perturbation series solution for the effective diffusion constant Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}, derived in section IV.2 are finite. In particularly we will show how a formula, which fits the numerical evaluation for the diffusion constant, can be derived for all values of Îµğœ€\varepsilon using a PadÃ© type re summation of the small Îµğœ€\varepsilon perturbation expansion along with the first two terms (the ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğ’ª1{\cal O}(1) and ğ’ªâ€‹(1/Îµ)ğ’ª1ğœ€{\cal O}(1/\varepsilon) ones) in the large Îµğœ€\varepsilon expansion derived in section VII. In addition we will demonstrate numerically certain of the key results derived in this paper in the large and small Îµğœ€\varepsilon regimes.

For the purposes of this section we consider the channel defined by

Î¶â€‹(x)=1.5+0.266â€‹[cosâ¡(2â€‹Ï€â€‹x)+sinâ¡(6â€‹Ï€â€‹x)].ğœğ‘¥1.50.266delimited-[]2ğœ‹ğ‘¥6ğœ‹ğ‘¥\zeta(x)=1.5+0.266\left[\cos(2\pi x)+\sin(6\pi x)\right]. (119)

Firstly we see that the solution vanishes within the part of the channel |Y|<Î¶mğ‘Œsubscriptğœğ‘š|Y|<\zeta_{m} to high numerical accuracy, while the solution becomes, as for the small Îµğœ€\varepsilon case, independent of Yğ‘ŒY in the region |Y|>Î¶mğ‘Œsubscriptğœğ‘š|Y|>\zeta_{m} and takes the approximate form fâ€‹(x,y)â‰ˆxğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥f(x,y)\approx x.

We now consider the accuracy of the perturbation theory developed in this paper based on the small Îµğœ€\varepsilon expansion, which for the smooth channel considered here is always well defined. Shown in Fig.Â 5a is the result of the perturbation theory starting at order ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}), through to that at ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ6)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}) along with the exact numerical evaluation of the diffusion constant. The results clearly improve with increasing the order of the perturbation expansion â€“ however, they all depart strongly from the exact result when Îµğœ€\varepsilon is ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğ’ª1{\cal O}(1). Furthermore the perturbation expansion appears to give lower bounds when taken at ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}) and ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ6)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}) and upper bounds when taken at ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€4{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{4}) (without any re summation). This alternating structure in the perturbation expansion is also seen for diffusion in random Gaussian potentials dea94 ; dea95 . The problem with this alternating structure of the perturbation theory is that the diffusion constant will either become negative or greater than Dğ·D (which is clearly not possible on physical grounds) depending on the order of perturbation theory employed. In addition, we have seen that Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e} saturates at large values of Îµğœ€\varepsilon which is incompatible with a pure polynomial expansion in Îµğœ€\varepsilon. Based on the ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}) result of perturbation theory a number of authors have proposed the following alternative forms, which of course agree at ğ’ªâ€‹(Îµ2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}) with the basic perturbation theory result. In our notation these alternative expressions are

DeD=1âŸ¨Î¶âŸ©sâ€‹âŸ¨Î¶âˆ’1âŸ©sâ€‹11+Îµ2â€‹âŸ¨Î¶â€²â£2/Î¶âŸ©s3â€‹âŸ¨Î¶âˆ’1âŸ©s,subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ·1subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœğ‘ subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğœ1ğ‘ 11superscriptğœ€2subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğœâ€²2ğœğ‘ 3subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğœ1ğ‘ \frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}\frac{1}{1+\varepsilon^{2}\frac{\langle\zeta^{\prime 2}/\zeta\rangle_{s}}{3\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}}, (120)

proposed in zwa1991 . Another alternative is given by

DeD=1âŸ¨Î¶âŸ©sâ€‹âŸ¨(1+Îµ2â€‹Î¶â€²â£2)13Î¶âŸ©sâˆ’1,subscriptğ·ğ‘’ğ·1subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœğ‘ superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscript1superscriptğœ€2superscriptğœâ€²213ğœğ‘ 1\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}\langle\frac{(1+\varepsilon^{2}\zeta^{\prime 2})^{\frac{1}{3}}}{\zeta}\rangle_{s}^{-1}, (121)

which was given in reg2001 . A third alternative is given by Eq.Â (87), originally proposed in kal2006 . The comparison of these approximations with the exact numerical evaluation for the diffusion constant for the case in hand is shown in Fig.Â 5b. The advantage of these formulations is that the effective diffusion constant is now bounded within the region [0,D]0ğ·[0,D]. However, in the limit of large Îµğœ€\varepsilon all these proposed forms predict that the diffusion constant becomes zero and all are significantly different from the exact result for Îµğœ€\varepsilon of order 1. The last question we will therefore address here is whether there is a way to tie up the small and large Îµğœ€\varepsilon results derived here to obtain a formula describing the effective diffusion constant for all values of Îµğœ€\varepsilon? Below we will pursue a PadÃ© like approximant scheme which exploits both regimes of the perturbation theory studied in this paper.

We begin by writing the small Îµğœ€\varepsilon expansion for the effective diffusivity given by Eq.Â (67)

The results of this approximation for the class of channels described by Eq.Â (119) is shown in Fig.Â 5b. We see that the resulting approximation is in very good agreement with the exact numerical results and that, as is to be expected, the maximum errors arise in the crossover region where Îµğœ€\varepsilon is of order 111.

IX Conclusion

In this paper we have examined the effective dispersion of Brownian particles in a channel geometry. Rather than attempting to write an effective one-dimensional diffusion equation to describe the system as in many past studies, we have exploited a direct formula for the effective diffusion constant which is obtained from the system of time independent equations Eqs.Â (24-27) which were derived here for completeness but are in agreement with a general theory of dispersion coefficients developed in gue2015a and gue2015b and also with the macro transport theory of Brenner bre1993 when applied to the channel problem dorfman2014assessing . Using a formulation in terms of analytic functions [Eqs.Â (24,25,26,27)], we were able to develop a compact formulation of the perturbation theory in channel width scale Îµğœ€\varepsilon. Notably we were able to show that the homogenization scheme proposed by Kalinay and Percus kal2006 gives the correct diffusion constant at order Îµ6superscriptğœ€6\varepsilon^{6}. The exact results of Zwanzig for parameterized channels and the piece wise linear approximation of kal2006 can be deduced from the formalism developed here in a very compact manner. Most studies on diffusion in channels are focused on narrow channels. The formalism developed here was also exploited to study wide channels, yielding a physically intuitive result in the limit or very large channels but also giving the first non-trivial correction which takes a remarkably universal form. Finally we were able to show how the small and large Îµğœ€\varepsilon expansions for the effective diffusion constant can be combined in a PadÃ© type approximant which accurately describe continuous channels for all values of Îµğœ€\varepsilon.

There are a number of potential extensions of this work based on the static approach proposed in gue2015a ; gue2015b which can be extended to systems having a current in their equilibrium states. This means that the approach could be applied to dispersion in channels with driving forces both along the channel and normal to the channel gho2010 ; bur2008 ; burada2009diffusion (arising from gravity for example). Furthermore the approach of gue2015a ; gue2015b can also be adapted to extract the finite time behavior of transport coefficients and could be applied to the problem of diffusion in channels.
